{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient delivered a baby with normal expulsion of the placenta, but is now experiencing bleeding per vaginam and has a hypotensive and boggy mass palpated per abdomen. These findings are suggestive of retained placental tissues. Placenta succenturiata refers to an accessory lobe of placenta, which is not relevant in this case. Adenomyosis is a condition where endometrial tissue grows into the muscular wall of the uterus, and it is not related to the current presentation. Membranous placenta is not a recognized medical term. Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall, and it can cause retained placental tissues. Therefore, the likely diagnosis in this case is C. Placenta accreta.", "answer_choice": "C"}
